I suspect we've been bamboozled again.

You jumped from the statement that Ashe’s bow is “of the stars” to the conclusion that she’s secretely working with the Watchers.  Just mentioning the Watchers, then Tahm Kench and Swain’s vague impugnments, and asking “Is she _really_ a hero?” is idle speculation at best and character assassination at worst.

Furthermore:

1) Tahm Kench is an evil, manipulative champion who thrives on corruption and misery.  He is not a psychologist dispensing useful information to allies and tough love to enemies.  Instead, Tahm tempts his allies with their darkest desires and his enemies with vicious insults, in both cases trying to overturn their psyches.  He is anything but a reliable source of information about champions.

2) Swain is arrogant, cynical, and vague.  Everything he says about other champions is negative, accusatory, and vague.  He is, again, not a reliable source of information about champions.  And furthermore, he never says that Ashe deceived her people; even were her bow not found at the Frost Queen’s Grave, she might have believed her own “claim”.

3) Arguing that someone is ideal and pure and no-one even insinuates anything wrong about, then proceeding to find some insinuations from whatever source, does not make those suggestions believable, much less prove that the character must therefore be the _opposite_.  You’re grasping at straws.

4) The story of the Three Queens has been repeated throughout the Freljordian lore.  One of them, Avarosa, has always acted like Ashe; another like Sejuani; the third, Lissandra.  If those stories mean anything, then Ashe is the Avarosa of her time, not just a second Void follower.

Ashe is peacefully uniting and rebuilding the Freljord.  She has ended her people’s feuds, brought the Barbarians to her side, and even made peace with Lissandra. The Avarosans breathe easy and free, logging and farming the rich southern land, while Sejuani and Lissandra’s followers raid and freeze respectively.  There are no strange sigils on her flag or bizarre rituals in her culture.

Why would you believe the flirtations of a notorious womanizer and accusations of two demons over what you can see with your own two eyes?

You're a bit harsh. OP's theory is far from proven, but it IS consistent with the few clues he picked up, and those clues can't be explained by *just* the public story about Ashe.

Maybe she's not following the Watchers, maybe it's something else entirely, maybe she doesn't actively deceive her people and does believe her claims herself. But something is clear, it's that we don't know the full truth yet and there are secrets to dig out. No harm in making hypothesis, even if those hypothesis turn out to be wrong later, it's still fun.

What I consider reasonably certain for now is that Ashe's bow isn't what it seems, because both Taric and Swain point in that direction. And that is already enough to question her position as the true heir of Avarosa. It's not enough to deny that she may well be a perfect spiritual successor to Avarosa, but her true heir, I doubt it.

Also, even if Swain/Tahm/Taric aren't exactly reliable sources of information, they aren't real people. They are characters, and some author/writer decided to put those words in their mouth for a good reason. It's usually not a good idea to give flat out lies to your audience, so even if what they say isn't the plain truth, you can probably assume there is some seed of truth hidden inside.

About the harshness: Ashe is one of my favorite champions, and unlike many players, I love that she’s a real hero with the power to change the world for the better.  When people say, “Oh, she’s not all she seems to be,” I get upset.  Moreover, speculation masquerading as an argument should irritate us all, since it’s misleading and can actually change people’s minds to the wrong opinion.

Ashe’s bow is made of ice, changed her hair color, shoots more arrows than otherwise possible, creates ice arrows, turned her hair white, lets her summon hawk spirits, and saved her from assassination after some of her tribesmen rejected her vision of peaceful unification.  That thing could not have belonged to anyone _but_ Avarosa.

At most, it could be argued that there is more to Ashe’s story than we know, but we already know that Freljordian lore will come with Nunu’s VGU.  The OP was trying to suggest that she’s secretly serving the Watchers.

Theory-crafting and speculation about clues definitely left here on purpose (so the writers WANT us to speculate) is not propaganda to turn people against your cause... 

And "speculation masquerading as an argument" means nothing. Ashe working for the Watchers is speculation. Swain/Taric VO is a valid argument that supports the speculation. Nothing is masquerading. Nothing is proven either, but that's not the same thing.

As for your argument that the bow couldn't have belonged to anyone but Avarosa, well.... It's entirely consistent with Anivia's powers, for instance. And I didn't say the bow didn't belong to Avarosa, I said the bow "isn't what it seems". Maybe Avarosa did use it, but he was given to her by Targonians, I don't know. But there is something here we're not told yet, and if the bow is magical due to something more than Avarosa's own power, it means probably anyone could use it, and so Ashe is not necessarily a direct descendant of Avarosa.

Yes, the OP was suggesting something not proven yet. That's the point of speculation. You happen to disagree with it and you're free to offer contradicting interpretations as you did in your first post, but you shouldn't shut them down like that. People seeing things differently than you do should be a source of more discussion and shared enjoyment with the lore. It shouldn't diminish your own love for the characters and the world.

A credible argument that a character is Void-aligned would change anyone’s outlook on them.  Presenting evidence supporting that argument but also other arguments (did the bow come from Aurelian Sol?) without even mentioning them ignores the possibility that they could be true and is misleading.

We’ve never had proof that Ashe is Avarosa’s descendant, but that was never how she was portrayed.  Taking up her bow and her cause of peace, justice, unity, and hope is what makes Ashe today’s Avarosa.  And speaking of what the authors might have meant, doesn’t the relationship between the three current Freljordian leaders and the three ancient queens seem obvious?

People seeing things differently than I do means that, at most, one of us is right.  I debate them to find out who, if any, is.  And if our judgments of the characters and world didn’t change afterward, then we must have been discussing a curiosity at best.  The subject raised by the OP is whether Ashe is _serving the end of Runeterra_.  Its truth   should change our judgments enormously.

Perhaps unwittingly, you are taking this discussion personally, interpreting my firm disagreement as a personal attack on the original poster, and are now trying to ‘keep the peace’ by making me feel guilty about my tone or approach.  I resent this behavior and will not reply if you continue.

What the hell? That last paragraph is unbelievable... Most important thing first... 

> by making me feel guilty about my tone or approach

... that's definitely not what I intended, and I apologize. As a rule of thumb, I don't try to manipulate people, and when I disagree I try to make it clear and to leave a choice to the other person, not to pressure them into agreeing.

With that out of the way, let's address the rest in order:

> Perhaps unwittingly, you are taking this discussion personally... 

You're the one who said "I get upset". You're the one *clearly* taking it personally, because you are attached to the character discussed. I'm not.

> ...  interpreting my firm disagreement as a personal attack on the original poster ...

Well, yeah? Your post boils down to "your theory is bullshit, your sources are useless, your post is a waste of time". That does sound like an attack to me, if not a personal one. There is "firm disagreement", and there is "shutting down the discussion entirely". But even if those clues OP found don't mean what he thinks they mean, they are still clues for *something* (I mean, a Red just confirmed it), and they deserve to be discussed.

> ... and are now trying to ‘keep the peace’ ...

It's not my place to "keep the peace", I'm not a mod, and that's not what I'm trying to do here. But as a fellow poster, I do think it's my place to try and create civil discussion on those boards. I do think you were out of line so I politely pointed that out, and then I proposed further arguments to move the discussion forward. To which you replied by once again shutting down the discussion entirely. So yeah, my next post was a bit firmer in saying "this is a discussion that deserves to be had". 

> ... by making me feel guilty about my tone or approach. I resent this behavior ...

The opposite of trying to make you feel guilty, I understood you were taking the topic personally, and I tried to give you a perspective to let you participate in the fun of the speculation without "getting upset" and shutting it down. I see that's not how it was received, and once again I'm sorry for the pain I caused, but you're giving me an ill-intent I never had...

>  ... and will not reply if you continue.

That's your call to make and I won't bother you further. My point is simply that this thread is a good discussion for the community to have, and that you shouldn't try to shut it down. And I do have replies to some of your points above, but addressing that last paragraph seemed more important and deserved a post of its own.

Super cool theory!

Just a tiny nitpick about Tahm Kench though.

I don't think his taunts are "what they want to hear" VS "the truth". I think the enemy taunts are simply what would hurt them, what would make them angry, what would make them lose focus and make mistakes. And a common way to do that is to use the truth, because people won't get angry if you say something obviously false, they'll just think you're crazy. But assuming Tahm ALWAYS use the truth is a big leap that I wouldn't take.

Specifically in Ashe's case, I'd say he is just toying with her fears, something that she herself has doubt about, something she wonders in her darkest hours. Tahm probably don't know better than Ashe herself, but by making it sound as if he does, he can torment her.

So that doesn't tell us that Ashe is obviously misguided (by following the Watchers or whatever), but it does tell us that Ashe herself isn't fully convinced by the hopes and vision that she sells to her people. Maybe because she's lying to them, but maybe because she's simply worried despite her best intentions.

Also all of these speculations we have are in the air as the lore of every character can change in many number of ways!

We also have to consider the factor of Masters of the Void now. Lissandra wouldn't really need these two at each other when Void is awakening!

I think the real story is Ashe wished for peace within the Freljord and made the ultimate crossroad deal to be able to wield Avarosa's Bow, at the cost of a future payment to the Watchers or whatever mysterious force she thought she was speaking with. She is trying to build an empire of peace, but she has payed costs that she can't possibly foresee to be so large. Ashe never realized how much using Avarosa's Bow is going to come back to bite her in the behind.

When the Watchers inevitably return, I think Ashe will find her bow isn't as loyal as she thought.

I think you're extrapolating a bit much here. First of all, there were 3 Sisters - each claiming to be the Frost Queen. Ultimately, Lissandra outlived Averosa and the other one, which left _her_ as the Frost Queen. Therefore, it can also be assumed that Swain's secret knowledge is that Avarosa isn't the Frost Queen - Lissandra is. Therefore, Ashe's assumption that she got the bow on the Frost Queen's grave is wrong since Lissandra isn't dead.

Taric's line towards Ashe is also pure smooth talking and flattery. I don't look very deep into many of his lines for other champions, and this is definitely one of them. 

As for Kench, his point about foresight is in reference to her dream and desire to unite the Freljord using peace and diplomacy. He's saying her dream is basically stupid, naïve, and ill-conceived because she's trying to unite war mongering using the wrong methods.
